greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the sum of the quadratic residues of n.
comment: The table below shows n, the number of nonzero quadratic residues (QRs) of n (A105612), the sum of the QRs of n and the nonzero QRs of n (A046071) for n = 1..10.

When p is prime >= 5, a(p) is a multiple of p by a variant of Wolstenholme's theorem (see A076409 and A076410). _Robert Israel_ remarks that we don't need Wolstenholme, just the fact that Sum_{x=1..p-1} x^2 = p*(2*p-1)*(p-1)/6. - _Bernard Schott_, Mar 13 2019
reference: G. H. Hardy and E. M. Wright, An Introduction to the Theory of Numbers. 4th ed., Oxford Univ. Press, 1960, pp. 88-90.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 terms from C. H. Gribble)
mathematica: residueQ[n_, k_] := Length[Select[Range[Floor[k/2]], PowerMod[#, 2, k] == n&, 1]] == 1;
program: a165909 n = sum $ nub $ map (`mod` n) $
(PARI) a(n) = sum(k=0, n-1, k*issquare(Mod(k,n))); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Mar 13 2019
xref: Row sums of A046071 and of A096008.
results.author: _Christopher Hunt Gribble_, Sep 30 2009
